definition: to leak/to expose (sb's secret)/to spill the beans/to let the cat out of the bag
to show/to reveal/to betray/to expose
dew/syrup/nectar/outdoors (not under cover)/to show/to reveal/to betray/to expose
surname Lu
stuffing/forcemeat/filling
erhua variant of 露餡|露馅[lou4 xian4]

sentences.english: Her veneer of politeness began to crack.
sentences.chinese: 她那彬彬有礼的伪装开始露馅儿了。

sentences.english: Just make sure to hide the wires, lest mess up the illusion.
sentences.chinese: 不过一定要把导线藏好，否则就露馅了。

sentences.english: As long as they are good fakes, other people won't know any different.
sentences.chinese: 只要假货不露馅，别人也就看不出差别。

sentences.english: But they betray themselves every_time they open their mouths.
sentences.chinese: 但他们每次开口说话就会露馅。

sentences.english: What betrayed the peddler who claimed to sell real diamonds?
sentences.chinese: 声称卖真钻石的小贩是怎样露馅的？

sentences.english: Their cloak of neutrality in the Iran-Iraq war was beginning to wear a bit thin.
sentences.chinese: 战争中表面上所采取的中立态度开始有点露馅了。

sentences.english: His words however rang untrue as he discussed his activities both in and outside of the prison.
sentences.chinese: 但谈起在监狱内外的活动时，他露馅了。

definition: erhua variant of 露餡|露馅[lou4 xian4]
to reveal the cloven foot (idiom); to unmask one's true nature/to give the game away
to reveal the cloven foot (idiom); to unmask one's true nature/to give the game away

(TV or movie) blooper/continuity error/(theater) to flub one's lines/unintended exposure of a body part/to be exposed (of a scheme or trick)/to reveal sth one intended to conceal through a slip of the tongue/to blow one's cover
sth one wishes to conceal/the cat (as in "let the cat out of the bag")
to expose/to uncover
to blurt out/to let slip
to expose/to unmask/to see through (a lie etc)
to puncture/to lay bear or expose (lies etc)
(of a plot etc) to fall through and stand exposed
to penetrate/to see through
to make a fool of oneself
to get away with it/to slip through/to bluff one's way out/Taiwan pr. [meng1 hun4 guo4 guan1]
to make a fool of oneself
to go wrong/to take a wrong turning
to patch up one's lie (when inconsistencies appear)/to cover (for sb who has lied)
